channel.title: Marketplace
channel.description: Every weekday, host Kai Ryssdal helps you make sense of the day’s business and economic news — no econ degree or finance background required. “Marketplace” takes you beyond the numbers, bringing you context. Our team of reporters all over the world speak with CEOs, policymakers and regular people just trying to get by.
channel.itunes:summary: Every weekday, host Kai Ryssdal helps you make sense of the day’s business and economic news — no econ degree or finance background required. “Marketplace” takes you beyond the numbers, bringing you context. Our team of reporters all over the world speak with CEOs, policymakers and regular people just trying to get by.
channel.itunes:author: Marketplace

item.title: How low should wage growth go?
item.itunes:title: How low should wage growth go?
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell received some welcome news in today’s jobs report: Wage growth is slowing a tad. The gains certainly aren’t as low as the Fed is hoping for, but the moderation could be a hint that the job market is starting to cool off. Plus, Twitter provides an example of how not to go about layoffs, and YouTube’s copyright tool sparks frustration for musicians.
item.itunes:summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell received some welcome news in today’s jobs report: Wage growth is slowing a tad. The gains certainly aren’t as low as the Fed is hoping for, but the moderation could be a hint that the job market is starting to cool off. Plus, Twitter provides an example of how not to go about layoffs, and YouTube’s copyright tool sparks frustration for musicians.

item.title: Potential holiday travel hiccups … already
item.itunes:title: Potential holiday travel hiccups … already
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Ahead of the holiday travel season, pilots at two major airlines rejected tentative contracts this week, and a third voted to authorize a strike. Pilots are bargaining for better wages and quality-of-life provisions, all while clocking record-high overtime and grappling with staff shortages. Also in this episode, worker productivity gets a boost, graphite shortages are bad news for EVs, and extreme heat threatens low-income households in Miami.
item.itunes:summary: Ahead of the holiday travel season, pilots at two major airlines rejected tentative contracts this week, and a third voted to authorize a strike. Pilots are bargaining for better wages and quality-of-life provisions, all while clocking record-high overtime and grappling with staff shortages. Also in this episode, worker productivity gets a boost, graphite shortages are bad news for EVs, and extreme heat threatens low-income households in Miami.

item.title: Not a matter of “when” but “how high?”
item.itunes:title: Not a matter of “when” but “how high?”
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The Federal Reserve announced another interest rate increase today. On the program, we’ll unpack the key questions on Fed Chair Jerome Powell’s mind as he guides the central bank in its quest to quell rising prices. Then, it’s back to Buffalo, New York, where we visit a food truck providing better access to fresh produce and reflect on what economists could learn from the people behind macroeconomic data.
item.itunes:summary: The Federal Reserve announced another interest rate increase today. On the program, we’ll unpack the key questions on Fed Chair Jerome Powell’s mind as he guides the central bank in its quest to quell rising prices. Then, it’s back to Buffalo, New York, where we visit a food truck providing better access to fresh produce and reflect on what economists could learn from the people behind macroeconomic data.

item.title: Not quite what the Fed’s looking for
item.itunes:title: Not quite what the Fed’s looking for
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: A cooling labor market means cooling inflation — at least in theory. But fresh data shows that job openings are growing and the quits rate remains high. Today, we’ll dig into the implications for workers and the Federal Reserve. Then, we’ll travel back to Buffalo, New York, to hear how the pandemic has altered the trajectories of a global hospitality company, a small inn and a young worker.
item.itunes:summary: A cooling labor market means cooling inflation — at least in theory. But fresh data shows that job openings are growing and the quits rate remains high. Today, we’ll dig into the implications for workers and the Federal Reserve. Then, we’ll travel back to Buffalo, New York, to hear how the pandemic has altered the trajectories of a global hospitality company, a small inn and a young worker.

item.title: A view of this economy from Buffalo, New York
item.itunes:title: A view of this economy from Buffalo, New York
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: We spend a lot of time on this program talking about the big-picture data of this economy. But data doesn’t tell the whole story. Today, we travel to Buffalo, New York — a city where low-wage workers have enjoyed wage growth of more than 40% in the past few years — and hear how workers along one street are navigating inflation, the labor market and recovery from the pandemic.
item.itunes:summary: We spend a lot of time on this program talking about the big-picture data of this economy. But data doesn’t tell the whole story. Today, we travel to Buffalo, New York — a city where low-wage workers have enjoyed wage growth of more than 40% in the past few years — and hear how workers along one street are navigating inflation, the labor market and recovery from the pandemic.

item.title: How much longer?
item.itunes:title: How much longer?
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Inflation is the unwanted guest who somehow has not taken the hint. Prices are still rising month over month. And though the Federal Reserve’s rate hikes are being felt throughout the economy, we’ll likely be asking that question for a while before prices start to stabilize. Plus, a race toward I bonds, a plan to keep college students in STEM and the economic woes of going on tour.
item.itunes:summary: Inflation is the unwanted guest who somehow has not taken the hint. Prices are still rising month over month. And though the Federal Reserve’s rate hikes are being felt throughout the economy, we’ll likely be asking that question for a while before prices start to stabilize. Plus, a race toward I bonds, a plan to keep college students in STEM and the economic woes of going on tour.

item.title: A rearview mirror report
item.itunes:title: A rearview mirror report
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Last quarter’s gross domestic product showed better-than-expected growth. Problem is, GDP is backward-facing, and a strong dollar, rising mortgage rates and slowing consumer spending all hint at trouble ahead. Later in the program: how schools are prepping to train chip production workers, why investment is pouring into quantum computer development and how a dark chapter of history spawned a booming tourism industry in Salem, Massachusetts.
item.itunes:summary: Last quarter’s gross domestic product showed better-than-expected growth. Problem is, GDP is backward-facing, and a strong dollar, rising mortgage rates and slowing consumer spending all hint at trouble ahead. Later in the program: how schools are prepping to train chip production workers, why investment is pouring into quantum computer development and how a dark chapter of history spawned a booming tourism industry in Salem, Massachusetts.

item.title: A vibe check for corporate America
item.itunes:title: A vibe check for corporate America
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: We’re in the throngs of earnings season. Corporate ​​earnings releases are kind of like report cards for large companies, and while many have beaten quarterly expectations so far, their outlooks tend to be a little less rosy. Today, we’ll check the mood of corporate America. Plus, schools weigh spending options for COVID relief funds, short-term mortgages worry British homeowners and small businesses see supply chain relief.
item.itunes:summary: We’re in the throngs of earnings season. Corporate ​​earnings releases are kind of like report cards for large companies, and while many have beaten quarterly expectations so far, their outlooks tend to be a little less rosy. Today, we’ll check the mood of corporate America. Plus, schools weigh spending options for COVID relief funds, short-term mortgages worry British homeowners and small businesses see supply chain relief.

item.title: Will renters finally catch a break?
item.itunes:title: Will renters finally catch a break?
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The last few years have been a roller coaster for renters. Though  rents are up roughly 9% year over year, that’s an improvement from the increases seen last year. Is this a sign that the rental market is finally moderating, or just a temporary seasonal dip? Plus, a boost in new car inventory, new pay transparency laws that encourage fair compensation and banks’ role in the racial wealth gap.
item.itunes:summary: The last few years have been a roller coaster for renters. Though  rents are up roughly 9% year over year, that’s an improvement from the increases seen last year. Is this a sign that the rental market is finally moderating, or just a temporary seasonal dip? Plus, a boost in new car inventory, new pay transparency laws that encourage fair compensation and banks’ role in the racial wealth gap.

item.title: The ripple effects of rising rates
item.itunes:title: The ripple effects of rising rates
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The Fed’s interest rate hikes continue to be felt across the economy. First, we’ll hear how those higher rates are luring investors away from tech companies, then we’ll see how decades-high mortgage rates are stretching the time houses remain on the market. Also on the program: Medicare recipients foot the bill for a rejected Alzheimer’s drug, and artificial intelligence rocks the digital art world.
item.itunes:summary: The Fed’s interest rate hikes continue to be felt across the economy. First, we’ll hear how those higher rates are luring investors away from tech companies, then we’ll see how decades-high mortgage rates are stretching the time houses remain on the market. Also on the program: Medicare recipients foot the bill for a rejected Alzheimer’s drug, and artificial intelligence rocks the digital art world.

item.title: The economic paradox of wildfire prevention
item.itunes:title: The economic paradox of wildfire prevention
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Last spring, the worst wildfire in New Mexico’s history grew from prescribed burns lit by the U.S. Forest Service. It cost the federal government billions and devastated hundreds of homes and businesses. Now, liability concerns are making the Forest Service more cautious about using the wildfire prevention tool — just as experts say it’s needed most. Plus, persistent global recession fears and the intentional dryness of earnings calls.
item.itunes:summary: Last spring, the worst wildfire in New Mexico’s history grew from prescribed burns lit by the U.S. Forest Service. It cost the federal government billions and devastated hundreds of homes and businesses. Now, liability concerns are making the Forest Service more cautious about using the wildfire prevention tool — just as experts say it’s needed most. Plus, persistent global recession fears and the intentional dryness of earnings calls.

item.title: A rejection of “Trussonomics”
item.itunes:title: A rejection of “Trussonomics”
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The United Kingdom’s economy was sent into a tailspin during Liz Truss’ six short weeks as prime minister. Today, we’ll check in with Marketplace’s London bureau chief to discuss the political and economic fallout of Truss’ resignation and hear what’s next for 10 Downing Street. We’ll also dissect the corporate strategies for price hikes, follow the money in midterm elections and weigh infrastructure improvement options for cash-strapped towns.
item.itunes:summary: The United Kingdom’s economy was sent into a tailspin during Liz Truss’ six short weeks as prime minister. Today, we’ll check in with Marketplace’s London bureau chief to discuss the political and economic fallout of Truss’ resignation and hear what’s next for 10 Downing Street. We’ll also dissect the corporate strategies for price hikes, follow the money in midterm elections and weigh infrastructure improvement options for cash-strapped towns.

item.title: Economic predictions, courtesy of the stock market
item.itunes:title: Economic predictions, courtesy of the stock market
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: It’s been a rough year for the stock market. But the stock market doesn’t always provide a clear roadmap of where the economy is headed. Today, the factors behind stock market volatility and how much we can read into the ups and downs. Also in the program: Europe turns to coal to avoid an energy crisis and a look at natural disaster modeling following Hurricane Ian.
item.itunes:summary: It’s been a rough year for the stock market. But the stock market doesn’t always provide a clear roadmap of where the economy is headed. Today, the factors behind stock market volatility and how much we can read into the ups and downs. Also in the program: Europe turns to coal to avoid an energy crisis and a look at natural disaster modeling following Hurricane Ian.

item.title: Big banks and Big Tech get recession-ready
item.itunes:title: Big banks and Big Tech get recession-ready
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Across the economy, companies are bracing for a cold economic winter. While banks are stockpiling cash to cover defaulted loans, tech companies like Microsoft are slimming staff and scaling back recruitment. In today’s episode, a look at how companies are prepping for an economic downturn. Plus, a silver lining for supply chains, second lives for school buildings and a nationalized green energy company proposal in the U.K.
item.itunes:summary: Across the economy, companies are bracing for a cold economic winter. While banks are stockpiling cash to cover defaulted loans, tech companies like Microsoft are slimming staff and scaling back recruitment. In today’s episode, a look at how companies are prepping for an economic downturn. Plus, a silver lining for supply chains, second lives for school buildings and a nationalized green energy company proposal in the U.K.

item.title: What’s at stake for the student loan forgiveness program
item.itunes:title: What’s at stake for the student loan forgiveness program
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The Department of Education recently opened its application for student loan forgiveness. With over 40 million people eligible for debt relief, it’s the largest operation of its kind in the department’s history. Today, we take a look at the logistics, hurdles and stakes for the federal government. Plus, a pricier holiday shopping season, a flawed economic indicator and a boost in accessibility for hearing aids.
item.itunes:summary: The Department of Education recently opened its application for student loan forgiveness. With over 40 million people eligible for debt relief, it’s the largest operation of its kind in the department’s history. Today, we take a look at the logistics, hurdles and stakes for the federal government. Plus, a pricier holiday shopping season, a flawed economic indicator and a boost in accessibility for hearing aids.

item.title: Inflation may be losing steam … here and there
item.itunes:title: Inflation may be losing steam … here and there
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Think of inflation as a runner. In parts of the economy, that runner is slowing — still going forward, just not as fast. Today, we’ll unpack which sectors are leading the race and which are faltering. Plus, how the Fed is tackling that persistent inflation, what a Kroger-Albertsons merger means for your grocery bill and how China’s economy is doing on the eve of its 20th Communist congress.
item.itunes:summary: Think of inflation as a runner. In parts of the economy, that runner is slowing — still going forward, just not as fast. Today, we’ll unpack which sectors are leading the race and which are faltering. Plus, how the Fed is tackling that persistent inflation, what a Kroger-Albertsons merger means for your grocery bill and how China’s economy is doing on the eve of its 20th Communist congress.

item.title: Forget the headline number! How are you feeling?
item.itunes:title: Forget the headline number! How are you feeling?
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Core inflation registered 6.6% in September on a yearly basis. But just how much pain you feel paying your bills depends on who you are and what those bills are for. In today’s show, a look at why the headline inflation figure is probably different from the inflation you feel. Plus, the factors behind sky-high airfares, the problem-solving prowess of women in leadership and the hurdles to correcting unequal federal policies.
item.itunes:summary: Core inflation registered 6.6% in September on a yearly basis. But just how much pain you feel paying your bills depends on who you are and what those bills are for. In today’s show, a look at why the headline inflation figure is probably different from the inflation you feel. Plus, the factors behind sky-high airfares, the problem-solving prowess of women in leadership and the hurdles to correcting unequal federal policies.

item.title: A rule that could upend the gig economy
item.itunes:title: A rule that could upend the gig economy
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: A recent proposal by the Joe Biden administration could reclassify gig workers as employees rather than independent contractors and expand benefits and protections for millions of Americans. Today, a look at what the move would mean for workers and companies. Also, big but slowing price increases for producers, a dramatic cooling in the mortgage business and a firsthand account of Hurricane Ian’s damage near Fort Myers, Florida.
item.itunes:summary: A recent proposal by the Joe Biden administration could reclassify gig workers as employees rather than independent contractors and expand benefits and protections for millions of Americans. Today, a look at what the move would mean for workers and companies. Also, big but slowing price increases for producers, a dramatic cooling in the mortgage business and a firsthand account of Hurricane Ian’s damage near Fort Myers, Florida.

item.title: A freight worker strike is back on the table
item.itunes:title: A freight worker strike is back on the table
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: A union representing freight railroad workers rejected the most recent tentative contract with major railroads, meaning that a strike — and threat to the supply chain — is once again possible. Today, we’ll take a look at the concerns over working conditions and the costs of a strike. Plus, a sign of small business optimism, a drop in computer demand and discussion of financial reparations following a wrongful conviction.
item.itunes:summary: A union representing freight railroad workers rejected the most recent tentative contract with major railroads, meaning that a strike — and threat to the supply chain — is once again possible. Today, we’ll take a look at the concerns over working conditions and the costs of a strike. Plus, a sign of small business optimism, a drop in computer demand and discussion of financial reparations following a wrongful conviction.

item.title: What a major cost-of-living bump means for Social Security recipients
item.itunes:title: What a major cost-of-living bump means for Social Security recipients
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Today, we’ll provide an economic preview for the week ahead. First, we’ll take a look at Social Security’s anticipated cost-of-living adjustment and hear what the historic increase would mean for recipients being squeezed by inflation. Then, we’ll dive into what Wall Street will be listening for in this week’s corporate earnings calls and check out the hefty discounts shoppers can expect this holiday season.
item.itunes:summary: Today, we’ll provide an economic preview for the week ahead. First, we’ll take a look at Social Security’s anticipated cost-of-living adjustment and hear what the historic increase would mean for recipients being squeezed by inflation. Then, we’ll dive into what Wall Street will be listening for in this week’s corporate earnings calls and check out the hefty discounts shoppers can expect this holiday season.

item.title: “Sliding doors” economics
item.itunes:title: “Sliding doors” economics
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The economy has made a remarkable recovery since the depths of the COVID-19 pandemic, but where would we be without that downturn? On today’s show, we talk “what ifs” with economists. Plus: semiconductor demand, oversharing on LinkedIn and what to make of the September jobs report.
item.itunes:summary: The economy has made a remarkable recovery since the depths of the COVID-19 pandemic, but where would we be without that downturn? On today’s show, we talk “what ifs” with economists. Plus: semiconductor demand, oversharing on LinkedIn and what to make of the September jobs report.

item.title: Why women have been left behind in the job recovery
item.itunes:title: Why women have been left behind in the job recovery
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: When the pandemic began, many working moms took a step back from their careers. Now, multitudes of women are still sidelined due to a lack of affordable, reliable child care. Today, how a worker shortage in the sector creates a barrier to women reentering the job market. Plus, potential food relief for Floridians reeling from Ian, a rural hospital’s reopening struggles and the battle over Iran’s internet censorship.
item.itunes:summary: When the pandemic began, many working moms took a step back from their careers. Now, multitudes of women are still sidelined due to a lack of affordable, reliable child care. Today, how a worker shortage in the sector creates a barrier to women reentering the job market. Plus, potential food relief for Floridians reeling from Ian, a rural hospital’s reopening struggles and the battle over Iran’s internet censorship.

item.title: A central question for the central bank
item.itunes:title: A central question for the central bank
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Critics are worried that the Federal Reserve is raising interest rates too quickly and may tip the economy into a recession without taming inflation. So what else can the Fed do? Today, we dive into the policy, politics and power at Fed Chair Jerome Powell’s fingertips. Plus, a squeeze in warehouse space, a predicted slowdown in global trade and the people locked out of China by its zero-COVID policy.
item.itunes:summary: Critics are worried that the Federal Reserve is raising interest rates too quickly and may tip the economy into a recession without taming inflation. So what else can the Fed do? Today, we dive into the policy, politics and power at Fed Chair Jerome Powell’s fingertips. Plus, a squeeze in warehouse space, a predicted slowdown in global trade and the people locked out of China by its zero-COVID policy.

item.title: When a shrinking job market isn’t so bad
item.itunes:title: When a shrinking job market isn’t so bad
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The number of job openings dipped 10% between July and August — a bigger drop than many economists predicted. It might show that the imbalance between supply and demand for labor is shrinking, and could be a sign that the Fed’s rate hikes are working. Plus, how workers are “performing” productivity, why importers are struggling to take advantage of a strong dollar, and when will this bear market finally end?
item.itunes:summary: The number of job openings dipped 10% between July and August — a bigger drop than many economists predicted. It might show that the imbalance between supply and demand for labor is shrinking, and could be a sign that the Fed’s rate hikes are working. Plus, how workers are “performing” productivity, why importers are struggling to take advantage of a strong dollar, and when will this bear market finally end?

item.title: For Europe, natural gas itself isn’t the problem. It’s the supply chain.
item.itunes:title: For Europe, natural gas itself isn’t the problem. It’s the supply chain.
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Europe is looking to boost imports of liquefied natural gas as winter approaches. But supply chain problems abound, from too few ships to transport natural gas and too few facilities to load and unload it. Today, a look at what it’ll take to solve Europe’s energy crisis. Plus, rising interest rates hit manufacturing, libraries are stretched thin and a vineyard tries to adapt to the climate crisis.
item.itunes:summary: Europe is looking to boost imports of liquefied natural gas as winter approaches. But supply chain problems abound, from too few ships to transport natural gas and too few facilities to load and unload it. Today, a look at what it’ll take to solve Europe’s energy crisis. Plus, rising interest rates hit manufacturing, libraries are stretched thin and a vineyard tries to adapt to the climate crisis.

item.title: Even economists can’t make sense of this economy
item.itunes:title: Even economists can’t make sense of this economy
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The economy seems full of contradictions right now. The threat of a recession looms and inflation is rampant, but consumers are still spending. Economists often look to history when making predictions, but the past offers little guidance to make sense of our current economic moment. Plus, the challenges of moving to more storm-resilient infrastructure and the toll of rising energy costs on U.K. businesses.
item.itunes:summary: The economy seems full of contradictions right now. The threat of a recession looms and inflation is rampant, but consumers are still spending. Economists often look to history when making predictions, but the past offers little guidance to make sense of our current economic moment. Plus, the challenges of moving to more storm-resilient infrastructure and the toll of rising energy costs on U.K. businesses.

item.title: Remember that container ship backlog?
item.itunes:title: Remember that container ship backlog?
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Last year, dozens of container ships waited off the Californian coast — some for weeks — to  dock and unload all the goods consumers were demanding. But those backlogs have eased substantially. Today, we’ll take a trip to the Marine Exchange of Southern California to hear what’s changed since and what hasn’t. Plus, why jobless claims are dipping and what Hurricane Ian means for Florida’s fragile insurance industry.
item.itunes:summary: Last year, dozens of container ships waited off the Californian coast — some for weeks — to  dock and unload all the goods consumers were demanding. But those backlogs have eased substantially. Today, we’ll take a trip to the Marine Exchange of Southern California to hear what’s changed since and what hasn’t. Plus, why jobless claims are dipping and what Hurricane Ian means for Florida’s fragile insurance industry.

item.title: The heavy cost of a strong dollar
item.itunes:title: The heavy cost of a strong dollar
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The U.S. dollar has been appreciating this year as investors take advantage of climbing interest rates. But the value of the dollar is forcing economies around the globe to pay the price. Today, we’ll delve into how a strong dollar is affecting imports, exports and the debts of foreign countries. Plus, the Bank of England makes a drastic move, and Hurricane Ian highlights power grid resilience.
item.itunes:summary: The U.S. dollar has been appreciating this year as investors take advantage of climbing interest rates. But the value of the dollar is forcing economies around the globe to pay the price. Today, we’ll delve into how a strong dollar is affecting imports, exports and the debts of foreign countries. Plus, the Bank of England makes a drastic move, and Hurricane Ian highlights power grid resilience.

item.title: A culprit behind rising prices? Remote work.
item.itunes:title: A culprit behind rising prices? Remote work.
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Plenty of folks who began working from home during the pandemic are still there. Today, we’ll take a look at how much that WFH reality may be pushing up housing costs and what it means for the Federal Reserve’s inflation fight. Plus, how portfolio dips affect your spending, how women’s colleges are responding to financial pressures and what Gallup’s CEO thinks about happiness and work.
item.itunes:summary: Plenty of folks who began working from home during the pandemic are still there. Today, we’ll take a look at how much that WFH reality may be pushing up housing costs and what it means for the Federal Reserve’s inflation fight. Plus, how portfolio dips affect your spending, how women’s colleges are responding to financial pressures and what Gallup’s CEO thinks about happiness and work.

item.title: A gloomy outlook for the global economy
item.itunes:title: A gloomy outlook for the global economy
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The stock market is not the economy. But financial markets around the world are looking at economic conditions right now and not liking what they’re seeing. Today, we’ll unpack the threats to global economic growth, which experts warn won’t let up anytime soon. Also, investors bail on British bonds, HIPAA excludes health apps and workers who cleaned a coal ash spill fight for compensation — and their lives.
item.itunes:summary: The stock market is not the economy. But financial markets around the world are looking at economic conditions right now and not liking what they’re seeing. Today, we’ll unpack the threats to global economic growth, which experts warn won’t let up anytime soon. Also, investors bail on British bonds, HIPAA excludes health apps and workers who cleaned a coal ash spill fight for compensation — and their lives.

item.title: Fasten your seatbelts, folks
item.itunes:title: Fasten your seatbelts, folks
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The soft landing the Federal Reserve hopes for the economy appears increasingly out of reach. Stocks tumbled this week and fears of a global recession loom, but Fed Chair Jerome Powell isn’t looking to back off his inflation fight. Today, we’ll try to chart the rocky path ahead. Plus, a look at natural gas reserves, a check-in with publishers and booksellers, and a taste of the nonalcoholic beverage industry.
item.itunes:summary: The soft landing the Federal Reserve hopes for the economy appears increasingly out of reach. Stocks tumbled this week and fears of a global recession loom, but Fed Chair Jerome Powell isn’t looking to back off his inflation fight. Today, we’ll try to chart the rocky path ahead. Plus, a look at natural gas reserves, a check-in with publishers and booksellers, and a taste of the nonalcoholic beverage industry.

item.title: A cautious approach to holiday hiring
item.itunes:title: A cautious approach to holiday hiring
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Around this time of year, companies begin hiring seasonal workers. Yet some large companies are planning on fewer hires. Despite a tight labor market, companies are uncertain whether consumer spending will remain strong through the holidays and are anxious about a recession. Plus, the Bank of Japan tries to prop up the yen, school districts call for cybersecurity funding and U.S. oil reserves reach a four-decade low.
item.itunes:summary: Around this time of year, companies begin hiring seasonal workers. Yet some large companies are planning on fewer hires. Despite a tight labor market, companies are uncertain whether consumer spending will remain strong through the holidays and are anxious about a recession. Plus, the Bank of Japan tries to prop up the yen, school districts call for cybersecurity funding and U.S. oil reserves reach a four-decade low.

item.title: “The bedrock of our economy”
item.itunes:title: “The bedrock of our economy”
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: That is how Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell characterized price stability while discussing the central bank’s interest rate hike Wednesday. The move pushes its benchmark rate to 3% or higher from zero in just six months. Today, we’ll explain what the Fed will be looking for to show that inflation is under control. Plus, what corporate layoffs tell us about the economy and how Germany is responding to its energy crisis.
item.itunes:summary: That is how Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell characterized price stability while discussing the central bank’s interest rate hike Wednesday. The move pushes its benchmark rate to 3% or higher from zero in just six months. Today, we’ll explain what the Fed will be looking for to show that inflation is under control. Plus, what corporate layoffs tell us about the economy and how Germany is responding to its energy crisis.

item.title: When the government pays more on its debt, so do you
item.itunes:title: When the government pays more on its debt, so do you
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: In anticipation of more rate hikes by the Federal Reserve this week, the yield on the 10-year Treasury note finished at the highest it’s been in more than a decade. In today’s episode, we’ll break down what a higher interest rate on the government’s debt means for everyday Americans, from higher rates on personal loans to a potential hiring slowdown. Plus, home prices still won’t come down, and many Puerto Ricans are without flood insurance.
item.itunes:summary: In anticipation of more rate hikes by the Federal Reserve this week, the yield on the 10-year Treasury note finished at the highest it’s been in more than a decade. In today’s episode, we’ll break down what a higher interest rate on the government’s debt means for everyday Americans, from higher rates on personal loans to a potential hiring slowdown. Plus, home prices still won’t come down, and many Puerto Ricans are without flood insurance.

item.title: Why do they call it a soft landing?
item.itunes:title: Why do they call it a soft landing?
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The Federal Reserve is all but guaranteed to raise interest rates this week. We’ll spend some time on today’s show talking about “soft landings,” and why hard landings are more common. Plus: Puerto Rico’s grid, the school band economy and retail shrinkage.
item.itunes:summary: The Federal Reserve is all but guaranteed to raise interest rates this week. We’ll spend some time on today’s show talking about “soft landings,” and why hard landings are more common. Plus: Puerto Rico’s grid, the school band economy and retail shrinkage.

item.title: Why your savings account’s interest rates are trailing the Fed’s
item.itunes:title: Why your savings account’s interest rates are trailing the Fed’s
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates yet again next week as it looks to double down on inflation. Even with all the rate hikes, interest rates on savings accounts are still lagging. Today, we’ll explore how supply and demand play a role. Plus, a data deep dive in the Weekly Wrap, an anticipated shipping downturn and a costly cleanup for the San Francisco Bay.
item.itunes:summary: The Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates yet again next week as it looks to double down on inflation. Even with all the rate hikes, interest rates on savings accounts are still lagging. Today, we’ll explore how supply and demand play a role. Plus, a data deep dive in the Weekly Wrap, an anticipated shipping downturn and a costly cleanup for the San Francisco Bay.

item.title: Your call is very important to the IRS
item.itunes:title: Your call is very important to the IRS
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Last year, the IRS only answered about 1 in 10 taxpayer calls, and the average wait time was 30 minutes. Thanks to new funding from the Inflation Reduction Act, the agency is set to hire 5,000 new customer service agents. On today’s show, we’ll look at why that hiring spree is easier said than done. Plus, retail sales send mixed signals, ethereum gets a major update, and Arizona juggles population growth with a limited water supply.
item.itunes:summary: Last year, the IRS only answered about 1 in 10 taxpayer calls, and the average wait time was 30 minutes. Thanks to new funding from the Inflation Reduction Act, the agency is set to hire 5,000 new customer service agents. On today’s show, we’ll look at why that hiring spree is easier said than done. Plus, retail sales send mixed signals, ethereum gets a major update, and Arizona juggles population growth with a limited water supply.

item.title: A grocery bill gut punch
item.itunes:title: A grocery bill gut punch
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: The August consumer price index shows that the cost of food at home was up 13.5% over the same period last year. That’s the largest annual increase since 1979, and higher energy prices, drought and the war in Ukraine all factor in. Also on today’s show: mortgage boycotts in China, stagnant household income in the U.S. and the tech that’s replacing business cards.
item.itunes:summary: The August consumer price index shows that the cost of food at home was up 13.5% over the same period last year. That’s the largest annual increase since 1979, and higher energy prices, drought and the war in Ukraine all factor in. Also on today’s show: mortgage boycotts in China, stagnant household income in the U.S. and the tech that’s replacing business cards.

item.title: Gas prices are down, everything else is up
item.itunes:title: Gas prices are down, everything else is up
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Almost everything became more expensive in August. We’ll discuss key items in the consumer price index and look at one number that dropped — the Census Bureau’s measure of child poverty rates. Plus, the U.S. enters a sorta trade agreement, a real estate agent talks housing market trends and researchers analyze plants to forecast wildfires.
item.itunes:summary: Almost everything became more expensive in August. We’ll discuss key items in the consumer price index and look at one number that dropped — the Census Bureau’s measure of child poverty rates. Plus, the U.S. enters a sorta trade agreement, a real estate agent talks housing market trends and researchers analyze plants to forecast wildfires.

item.title: The supply chain may be derailed again
item.itunes:title: The supply chain may be derailed again
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: We’ve learned just how fragile the global supply chain is the past few years, and we’re not out of the woods yet. Today, we examine two threats to the supply chain’s recovery: a potential strike of U.S. rail workers and continued lockdowns in China. We’ll also take a look at a new merchant code used for gun sales and hear how food banks are grappling with rising food costs.
item.itunes:summary: We’ve learned just how fragile the global supply chain is the past few years, and we’re not out of the woods yet. Today, we examine two threats to the supply chain’s recovery: a potential strike of U.S. rail workers and continued lockdowns in China. We’ll also take a look at a new merchant code used for gun sales and hear how food banks are grappling with rising food costs.

item.title: What’s cooking with the restaurant industry?
item.itunes:title: What’s cooking with the restaurant industry?
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: A new report says restaurant bookings are back to pre-COVID-19 levels, which should be good news, but profitability in the industry is down. We’ll talk to some restauranteurs about menu changes, customer attitudes and fears around raising prices. Plus, “The Big Bang Theory” vs. Chinese censors, a new “affordable” Chevy EV, and the Fed chair’s recent remarks about “economic pain.”
item.itunes:summary: A new report says restaurant bookings are back to pre-COVID-19 levels, which should be good news, but profitability in the industry is down. We’ll talk to some restauranteurs about menu changes, customer attitudes and fears around raising prices. Plus, “The Big Bang Theory” vs. Chinese censors, a new “affordable” Chevy EV, and the Fed chair’s recent remarks about “economic pain.”

item.title: The economy Queen Elizabeth leaves behind
item.itunes:title: The economy Queen Elizabeth leaves behind
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II was a symbol of stability for many, and her death comes at a turbulent time for the United Kingdom. Marketplace’s London bureau chief tells us about the mood of the country amid decades-high inflation and a transfer of power at 10 Downing Street. Plus, the strong dollar weighs down foreign economies and the European Central Bank unleashes an aggressive rate hike.
item.itunes:summary: Queen Elizabeth II was a symbol of stability for many, and her death comes at a turbulent time for the United Kingdom. Marketplace’s London bureau chief tells us about the mood of the country amid decades-high inflation and a transfer of power at 10 Downing Street. Plus, the strong dollar weighs down foreign economies and the European Central Bank unleashes an aggressive rate hike.

item.title: Out with the old rules
item.itunes:title: Out with the old rules
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Amid an inventory glut and flagging profits, Target said its 63-year-old CEO will stay on for three more years, even though he was mandated to retire in two. The retailer joins a growing list of companies to nix age limits in the C-suite. Today, we’ll dig into why the rule exists but is falling out of fashion. Plus, an equal pay win for the U.S. women’s soccer team and a TikToker who makes monetary policy fun.
item.itunes:summary: Amid an inventory glut and flagging profits, Target said its 63-year-old CEO will stay on for three more years, even though he was mandated to retire in two. The retailer joins a growing list of companies to nix age limits in the C-suite. Today, we’ll dig into why the rule exists but is falling out of fashion. Plus, an equal pay win for the U.S. women’s soccer team and a TikToker who makes monetary policy fun.

item.title: Electric slide: How the energy crisis in Europe could affect everything
item.itunes:title: Electric slide: How the energy crisis in Europe could affect everything
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Russia said Friday it would not resume pumping natural gas to Europe through the Nord Stream pipeline. By Monday, one gas benchmark had shot up 30%. Governments are spending big to keep utility companies afloat, which could be pushing some countries to the brink of financial crisis. We’ll talk about it, plus energy news stateside and a sobering look at problem gambling as legal sports betting expands.
item.itunes:summary: Russia said Friday it would not resume pumping natural gas to Europe through the Nord Stream pipeline. By Monday, one gas benchmark had shot up 30%. Governments are spending big to keep utility companies afloat, which could be pushing some countries to the brink of financial crisis. We’ll talk about it, plus energy news stateside and a sobering look at problem gambling as legal sports betting expands.

item.title: Big wins for the labor movement on this Labor Day
item.itunes:title: Big wins for the labor movement on this Labor Day
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Today, California Gov. Gavin Newsom signed a law aimed at improving wages and working conditions for fast food workers in the state. It’s an industrywide victory for the labor movement in a year that’s seen plenty of union wins. In today’s show, we’ll check the pulse of labor organizing in the U.S. Plus, a change to questions asked in federal labor surveys and a celebrity’s crusade for child literacy.
item.itunes:summary: Today, California Gov. Gavin Newsom signed a law aimed at improving wages and working conditions for fast food workers in the state. It’s an industrywide victory for the labor movement in a year that’s seen plenty of union wins. In today’s show, we’ll check the pulse of labor organizing in the U.S. Plus, a change to questions asked in federal labor surveys and a celebrity’s crusade for child literacy.

item.title: A Goldilocks jobs report
item.itunes:title: A Goldilocks jobs report
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Today, we’ll unpack the August national jobs report, which shows job growth as not too hot, not too cold. We’ll also look into who shoulders the burden of the employment slowdown most and who’s coming in off the sidelines of the labor market. Plus, inflation hits rural America harder, and a union representing musicians takes aim at streaming services.
item.itunes:summary: Today, we’ll unpack the August national jobs report, which shows job growth as not too hot, not too cold. We’ll also look into who shoulders the burden of the employment slowdown most and who’s coming in off the sidelines of the labor market. Plus, inflation hits rural America harder, and a union representing musicians takes aim at streaming services.

item.title: The business of TikTok trends
item.itunes:title: The business of TikTok trends
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: There’s promise and peril on the For You page. On today’s show, we’ll look at how companies cash in or miss out on the big TikTok trends — and why some of those viral fads aren’t as spontaneous as they look. But first: the dust-up over chip exports to China, the Volatility Index and the latest productivity numbers.
item.itunes:summary: There’s promise and peril on the For You page. On today’s show, we’ll look at how companies cash in or miss out on the big TikTok trends — and why some of those viral fads aren’t as spontaneous as they look. But first: the dust-up over chip exports to China, the Volatility Index and the latest productivity numbers.

item.title: The pandemic is over (for the government)
item.itunes:title: The pandemic is over (for the government)
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: Congress hasn’t approved new COVID funding for about a year and a half, and there’s not a whole lot of money left. With the FDA approving new boosters today, we’ll look at what happens when the cash runs out. Plus: A new way to track employment, a portrait of precarity in the restaurant business and a temp check on the American consumer.
item.itunes:summary: Congress hasn’t approved new COVID funding for about a year and a half, and there’s not a whole lot of money left. With the FDA approving new boosters today, we’ll look at what happens when the cash runs out. Plus: A new way to track employment, a portrait of precarity in the restaurant business and a temp check on the American consumer.

item.title: Not quite what the Fed’s going for
item.itunes:title: Not quite what the Fed’s going for
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: In the current inflation-whipped economy, it can feel like everything is going up. But a figure economists didn’t expect to increase was job openings. Today, we’ll dig into what that means for the labor market as the central bank tries to tap the brakes on the economy. Later, Russian pipeline repairs stoke anxiety in Europe, and rent caps come with a tricky balancing act.
item.itunes:summary: In the current inflation-whipped economy, it can feel like everything is going up. But a figure economists didn’t expect to increase was job openings. Today, we’ll dig into what that means for the labor market as the central bank tries to tap the brakes on the economy. Later, Russian pipeline repairs stoke anxiety in Europe, and rent caps come with a tricky balancing act.

item.title: An economic double-take
item.itunes:title: An economic double-take
item.itunes:author: Marketplace / Kai Ryssdal
item.description: At first glance, the U.S. economy is in kind of a weird place right now. Inflation remains high and the Fed isn’t backing down from interest rate hikes. But today we’ll take a closer look at two economic bright spots: the strength of the U.S. dollar and the surplus of job openings. Plus, a hurdle for Manhattan’s return-to-office plans and home flippers’ impact on design trends.
item.itunes:summary: At first glance, the U.S. economy is in kind of a weird place right now. Inflation remains high and the Fed isn’t backing down from interest rate hikes. But today we’ll take a closer look at two economic bright spots: the strength of the U.S. dollar and the surplus of job openings. Plus, a hurdle for Manhattan’s return-to-office plans and home flippers’ impact on design trends.
